Prompt_Text: I need to start working on new requirements without breaking my current app. Show me the git commands to create and switch to a new branch named 'feature-compliance-doc-flow'.

Update my 'raw_materials.json' generation script. 1. Add two new fields to every item: 'cas_number' (format: XXXX-XX-X) and 'inci_name' (e.g. 'Tocopherol'). 2. Ensure that interchangeable parts share the same CAS/INCI but have different Suppliers. 3. Remove 'SKU' as the primary lookup and use CAS_Number instead.

Modify the data generator further. Add a 'compliance_package' dictionary to every item. It should have 11 keys representing required documents (e.g., 'sds', 'tech_drawing', 'non_gmo_cert', 'animal_testing_statement', 'allergen_statement', etc.). Set their values to boolean True/False randomly, where only 20% of items have all 11 set to True.

Write a new Python function called 'check_compliance_completeness'. It takes an item's 'compliance_package'. Logic: 1. Count how many keys are True. 2. If count < 11, return 'MISSING_DOCS' and list which ones are False. 3. If count == 11, return 'READY_FOR_R&D'.

Create a python script called 'supplier_portal_sim.py'. It should simulate a supplier uploading a missing document. 1. Ask user for a CAS Number. 2. Show missing docs. 3. Allow user to type 'upload sds'. 4. Update the JSON file to set 'sds' to True for that item.

Update the main simulation flow. When 'check_compliance_completeness' returns 'READY_FOR_R&D', trigger a Bedrock prompt. Prompt: 'You are a Procurement Agent. The supplier [SupplierName] has submitted all 11 compliance docs for [INCI Name]. Write a polite email to them requesting a 100g sample for our Lab Batch testing. Reference the specific CAS number.'

Create a validation script. It should search the database for all items with the same CAS Number. Print a comparison table showing their Price vs. their 'Compliance Score' (x/11 docs ready). This helps R&D see if the cheaper option is actually 'paperwork ready'.
